content.description: Climb nice arete.
content.protection: Few hangers. Tree at the top.
content.location: Corridor. About 10ft. right of Dakota Blues.

content.description: Climb the right side of flake , then some nice face climbing to anchors at the top.
content.location: 5 ft. to the left of The Theater.

content.description: Climb face and arete to the top.
content.location: Corridor. 5 ft. left of Throb. Between the point and main cliffline, going right to left.

content.description: Nice and pumpy sport/trad Was featured on the cover of Climbing Magazine 1992, White arete. I was informed that a couple of years ago this route has went free.
content.protection: Has two hangers and the rest small pro to the top.
content.location: About 5 ft. past Pocket Wilderness to the right. On the obvious arete.

content.description: Some good trad through a hollow flake through a hanger and finish with some more crack climbing to anchors at the top.
content.location: 10 or so ft. to the left of Throb.

content.description: Start with a crimpy boulder problem, leading to better open-handed holds. Pump out left on an exposed rail traverse and bust over the roof onto the beautiful headwall. Fight through a final redpoint crux involving long moves on perfect sculpted holds. Take in the view, it doesn't get much better.
content.location: Located at the center of the Soul Sounds buttress underneath an obvious diagonal left-angling roof crack/traverse at the left end of an enormous roof.

content.description: Climb nice, but long tight seam through white face.
content.protection: 3 new hangers . Cold shuts have been replaced at the top..
content.location: 20 ft. or so past Who Shot Bambi.

content.description: The route starts on very solid choss, but can feel sandy.  Climb through a thuggy roof that requires kneebars and crack technique.  Pull over the roof to a perfect sandstone face.  A not so hard mantel leads to crimps and a big move.  It’s really nice climbing.
content.protection: Bolts.  It’s helpful to use runner or longer quick draws near the start.
content.location: It’s on the far left on the soul sound buttress.  It’s not too hard to pick out.  Look for choss that leads to a perfect sandstone face.  You have to get onto a big block to start the route.

content.description: Good face climb that lives up to its name.
content.location: To the right of Off To The Wild Blue Yonder.

content.description: Nice and clean sport route, if you do 12's this is for you.
content.location: 5 or so feet right past Cracksmiths Delight.

climbs.name: Off To The Wild Blue Yonder

content.description: Nice pumpy sport climbing.
content.location: 20 ft. to the right of The Tall Cool One.

content.description: Nice steep face climb.
content.location: 10 or so feet past Beefeater.

content.description: Crux is close to the top. Very nice route. Less than vertical/slab. Arete is off, if you use arete its 5.10 and you might be a mandy pandy!
content.protection: Belay station w/anchors to start. 4 hangers and top anchors. Top out!
content.location: North side of the point. under decent overhang.   You rap down to a ledge with belay station.   When you are crossing the Tyrolean you'll see it on the left.

content.description: Traverse to the left to a horizontal, then to a ledge. Finish up left to anchors.
content.location: 10 or 12 ft. left of Steal The Air.

content.description: At the end of the crack on Crack Of Dawn, follow face with two hangers to the top.
content.protection: Trad rack, and a couple of draws.
content.location: Same as Crack Of Dawn.

content.description: Nice face climb in the corridor and finish just to the right of a tree.
content.protection: Sport rack. Two hangers and a tree. Two ring anchors have been added to the top.
content.location: On the point where the corridor seperates the cliff line from the point.

content.description: Very nice face climbing to the top. With a view.
content.location: 8 ft. right of Cinderella.

content.description: Nice trad. Finger and Hand.
content.location: About 10 ft. right of Leapin Lizards.

content.description: Boulder up to a thin crack that splits a roof  and the face. Where the cracks stops move right and finish on the arete.
content.location: About 20 or so feet from Pump It To The Sky. To the right.

content.description: Climb short seam, with a right facing corner.   Finishes the same as Cuyahoga Falls.
content.location: To the right of Snow White.

content.description: Climb a nice thin vertical seam to the top.
content.location: Just right of Ambition Ammunition. Really nice orange face.Steep!

content.description: Nice pumpy face climb.
content.location: A few feet past A.I.D.S. crack. To the right.

content.description: Start on obvious crack, then move left where the arete becomes more prominent and finish on arete past one bolt to the top.
content.protection: Med pro and draw. Rap ring at the top.
content.location: starts with A.I.D.S. crack then moves left to the arete.

content.description: This is the same route as The Ugly Route.Climb the first pitch of Ugly Route and climb past the anchor to the top.
content.location: Starts with The Ugly Route.

content.description: Sweet hand/fist crack.
content.protection: Med to B.D. #4 , rap from rap-ring's The tree that is at the top is dead, but the chain is still there.....like I said the tree is dead, as in "will break"!
content.location: A few feet past Cuyahoga Falls.

content.description: Really nice area in Laurel/Snow Falls in Pocket Wilderness. On a huge point dividing the gorge. This Buttress has good sun most of the day. Rock quality is good. Has been awhile since some of the anchors have been replaced due to the access problems in in the past. Nice fall/winter sport crag. And some spicy trad. A lot of these routes are done with old school style in mind. A lot of these routes were started probably in 1977 with the likes of Rob Robinson and Bruce Rodgers. Then around the early 80's some other southern climbers came on the scene like James Dobbs,Ron Davis,Charles Kable, Shannon Stegg, Chris Chesnutt, along with Jeff Gruenberg and his hard line "Pieta" which might have very well been the first 5.14 in the southern realm. Later Rob Robinson and Glenn Ritter put more lines into play. Some of these routes are on the Point.
